Andrews, R., and R. Righter. 1992. Colorado birds:a reference to their distribution and habitat. Denver Museum Natural History xxxviii + 442 pp.
Cannings, R. A., R. J. Cannings, and S. G. Cannings. 1987. Birds of the Okanagan Valley, British Columbia. Royal British Columbia Museum, Victoria.

Monson, G. and A. Phillips. 1981. Annotated checklist of the birds of Arizona. University of Arizona
Press, Tucson.

Greene, Erick, William Davison and Vincent R. Muehter. 1998. Steller's Jay (Cyanocitta stelleri), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/343.

Kingery, Hugh E. (ed). 1998. Colorado Breeding Bird Atlas Colorado Bird Atlas Project (CBAP) and
Colorado Division of Wildlife, Publishers.
Stewart, A. C. and M. G. Shepard. 1994. Steller's Jay Invasion of Southern Vancouver Island, British Columbia. N. Am. Bird Bander 19:90-95.

mixed-coniferous forest. Condor 80:431-441.

Alcorn, J. R. 1988. The birds of Nevada. Fairview West Publishing, Fallon, NV.

Hile, A. G. 1993. Densities and substrate use of Scrub Jays (Aphelocoma coerulescens) and Steller's Jays (Cyanocitta stelleri) at Mt. Pinos, California. Master's Thesis. California State Univ. Northridge.

Goguen, C.B. and M.E. Mathews. 1998. Songbird community composition and nestling success in
grazed and ungrazed pinyon-juniper woodlands. Journal of Wildlife Management. 62(2):474-484
Rosenstock, S.S. 1998. Influence of gambel oak on breeding birds in ponderosa pine forests of northern Arizona. Condor. 100:485-492.
Garrett, K. and J. Dunn. 1981. Birds of southern California: status and distribution. Los Angeles Audubon Soc. Los Angeles, CA.
Hayward, C.L., C. Cottam, A.M. Woodbury, and H.H. Frost. 1976. Birds of Utah. Brigham Young University Press, Provo, UT.
Grinnell, J. and A. H. Miller. 1944. The distribution of the birds of California. Pac. Coast Avifauna no. 27. Cooper Ornithol. Club, Berkeley, CA.
habitat_description:
All Regions:
In California, this species is a common, year-round resident of foothill and mountain forests, preferring conifers but utilizes hardwood forests as well. It occupies higher elevation habitats during summer and generally moves downslope in winter (Green et al. from Zeiner et al. 1990, Grinnell and Miller 1944). It is rare in the Central Valley and coastal lowlands in winter months (McCaskie et al. 1979, Garrett and Dunn 1981).
In the northwest, the species is associated with humid coniferous forest, whereas in the southwest, habitats are more likely interior, arid pine-oak. Interior populations occupy habitats at elevations from 1000 to 3500 meters however, more coastal areas have no lower elevation limit.
Reported breeding in the following habitat types: subalpine forests of western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla) and Douglas-fir forests in British Columbia (Cannings et al. 1987); western hemlock, Douglas-fir, amabilis fir (Abies amabilis), grand fir (A. grandis), western red cedar (Thuja plicata), and Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) on Vancouver I., British Columbia (Stewart and Shepard 1994); spruce-fir (Picea-Abies) forests, lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta), mixed ponderosa–Douglas-fir forests in w. Montana (McEneaney 1993); mixed forest of coast live oak (Quercus agrifolia), eucalyptus (Eucalyptus spp.) groves, and California laurel (Umbellularia californica) near Berkeley, CA (Brown 1964, Salata 1982); piñon pine–scrub oak (Pinus monophylla-Quercus berberidifolia) and Jeffrey pine (Pinus jeffreyi) in Kern and Ventura Cos., CA (Hile 1993); ponderosa pine, Douglas-fir, piñon-juniper (Pinus–Juniperus), lodgepole pine, and spruce-fir forests in Colorado (Andrews and Righter 1992)(quoted directly from Greene et al. 1998).
In winter, low-elevation populations typically remain on breeding territories during winter in North America (Bent 1946, Brown 1964). High-elevation populations typically move to lower elevations during winter, and into habitats not occupied during breeding season, such as oak forests, orchards, and gardens (Bent 1946, Stewart and Shepard 1994)(quoted directly from Greene et al. 1998).

Southwest:
Breeding: coniferous and mixed-coniferous deciduous forest, open woodland, orchards and gardens, arid pine-oak associations in southwestern U.S (Greene et al. 1998). Pinyon pine depends on this species to disperse seeds for enhancement of germination (Christensen and Whitham 1991). Is a common resident in Arizona of pine, fir, and spruce forests throughout the state (Monson and Phillips 1981). Found in winter in southeastern Arizona in oak grassland dominated by Quercus emoryi and Q. oblongifolia, with grasses dominated by Bouteloua and Pleuraphis (Hilaria) (Westcott 1969).  In the Chiracahua Mountains of southeastern Arizona, can be found in ponderosa pine woodlands, with major species of Pinus ponderosa, Pinus strobiformis, Pseudotsuga menziesii, Quercus hypoleucoides, and Juniperus deppeana (Balda 1969). Found in northern Arizona at breeding time in Ponderosa pine (Pinus ponderosa)  communities and Ponderosa pine-Gambel oak (Quercus gambelii) communities, with an herbaceous understory of Arizona fescue (Festuca arizonica) and blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis) (Rosenstock 1998).  Found in mixed-coniferous forests in the White Mountains of Arizona (Franzreb and Ohmart 1978). A casual fall and winter visitor during flight years to the lower Colorado River Valley (Rosenberg et al. 1991). In Colorado, is a fairly common resident in foothills and lower mountains (Andrews and Righter 1992). In southern Colorado and along the Front Range, it is most common in ponderosa pine and douglas-fir forests; elsewhere it also occurs in pinyon-juniper, lodgepole pine, and locally in spruce-fir forests (Andrews and Righter 1992). Resident in some mountain ranges in Nevada (Alcorn 1988). In southern Nevada, occurs as a permanent resident in montane forests and as a visitant in riparian and woodland areas (Alcorn 1988). A post-breeding pair were taken in an open stand of mature ponderosa pine, bristlecone pine, and white fir in the Quinn Canyon Mountains of Nevada (Alcorn 1988). Common though irregular resident of coniferous forests and adjacent mountain shrub areas throughout the mountains of Utah (Hayward et al. 1976). Found as a resident in Colfax County, New Mexico in grazed and ungrazed rangeland consisting of blue grama (Bouteloua gracilis), pinyon pine (Pinus edulis), and one-seed juniper (Juniperus monosperma) (Goguen and Mathews 1998).  Occurs at 1,000-3,500 m (Greene et al. 1998). Breeds from 1,830-2,745 m in Colorado (Kingery 1998). Primarily found at 2,134-3,049 m in New Mexico (Ligon 1961).
